010package imagingbook.common.sift.scalespace;
011
012/**
013 * <p>
014 * Represents a single "octave" in a hierarchical DoG scale space. See Secs.
015 * 25.1.3 - 25.1.4 of [1] for more details.
016 * </p>
017 * <p>
018 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
019 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
020 * </p>
021 * 
022 * @author WB
023 * @version 2022/11/20
024 */
025public class DogOctave extends ScaleOctave {
026
027        // TODO: check correctness of bottom and top levels!!
028        DogOctave(ScaleOctave Gp) {
029                //super(0,0,0,0);
030                super(Gp.p, Gp.Q, Gp.width, Gp.height, Gp.botLevelIndex, Gp.topLevelIndex-1);
031                // create DoG octave
032                for (int q = botLevelIndex; q <= topLevelIndex; q++) {
033                        ScaleLevel Dpq = differenceOfGaussians(Gp.getLevel(q+1), Gp.getLevel(q));
034                        this.setLevel(q, Dpq);
035                }
036        }
037        
038        public ScaleLevel differenceOfGaussians(ScaleLevel A, ScaleLevel B) {
039                // A: Gaussian at level q+1
040                // B: Gaussian at level q
041                // C <-- A - B (scale the same as B)
042                ScaleLevel C = B.duplicate();
043                final float[] pixelsA = (float[]) A.getPixels();
044                final float[] pixelsB = (float[]) B.getPixels();
045                final float[] pixelsC = (float[]) C.getPixels();
046                for (int i = 0; i < pixelsA.length; i++) {
047                        pixelsC[i] = pixelsA[i] - pixelsB[i];
048                }
049                C.setAbsoluteScale(B.getAbsoluteScale());
050                return C;
051        }
052        
053}
